bibl.title: Letter from [Laura Armistead Carter] to William E. Deeks, May 5, 1924

div1.p: [Laura Carter] discusses the Carters' travel plans for a conference in Kingston, Jamaica. She mentions Henry Carter's health.

div1.head: Letter from [Laura Armistead Carter] to William E. Deeks, May 5, 1924

opener.dateline:
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
May 5, 1924.

div1.p:
Father and I would have written sooner to acknowledge and
thank you for your much appreciated invitation to the International
Conference at Kingston and the complimentary passes therefor, but
have been waiting for Drs. Thayer and Parker to go over Father so
as to be able to advise you more definitely as to the probability
of his being able to go. Dr. Thayer has had to postpone his com-
ing over, but Dr. Parker was here yesterday and, after going over
Father very carefully, said that he thought it would be all right
for him to take the trip, since I told him that you said it would
involve very little physical exertion and no going up stairs--the
one thing positively forbidden. I can't tell you how glad we both
are at the prospect of going! The fact of you and Dr. Thayer be-
ing along makes me feel so safe about Father, besides being an
assurance of delightful companionship.

As to our itinerary: I understood from you when you were
here the other day that you had already reserved passage for us
on the boat on which you, and most of your guests, were sailing on
July 12th. (The “Calamares” (?)) for Havana and thence to Kingston.

After the Conference we'd like to make whatever part of the visit
to the Divisions of the United Fruit Company you or Thayer make and
come back via Panama and New York, the time for leaving Panama being,
if possible, the same as your own. That's “playing safe” all the
way through, both for Dad's health, my peace of mind and our mutual
enjoyment.

The book goes on apace, but I've ceased to prophesy as to just
when we will complete these finishing touches to Section 111. We
are looking forward to your comment and criticism. I know you will
enjoy it, for you can appreciate it from so many angles: epidemio-
logical, archaelogical, clinical and literary. It really is a won-
derful piece of work, if “I do say it as hadn't oughter.”

Once more with warmest thanks and remembrances from us both
and with love to Mrs. Deeks and the nina.

closer.seg:
P. S. By the way, when you were at McGill, didn't you have
some classes under a Dr. Penhallow? He had the chair of Botony.
His son, who was in charge of a British military hospital from
1915 on, is the Medical Officer in Command at Mt. Alto here and
his widowed mother, who lives with him, says she is sure that she
remembers you, both from having met you as a student and as one of
whom her husband spoke very highly. She was very sorry to hear
that you had been in Washington and she had not known of it.
